column7: Open places in meadows, river sides, sandy coasts, and open deciduous forests of lowlands and montane regions[275].
column16: Lonicera morrowii is a deciduous Shrub growing to 2 m (6ft) by 3 m (9ft).  See above for USDA hardiness. It is hardy to UK zone 3.  It is in flower from May to June. The species is hermaphrodite (has both male and female organs) and is pollinated by Insects.  Suitable for: light (sandy), medium (loamy) and heavy (clay) soils. Suitable pH: mildly acid, neutral and basic (mildly alkaline) soils. It cannot grow in the shade. It prefers  moist soil.
column21: Fruit - raw[105, 179]. There is a question mark as to whether this fruit might be poisonous, or perhaps cathartic and emetic[105, 179]. The fruit is about 7mm in diameter[200].
column22: Cathartic: A strong laxative but less violent than a purgative.,Emetic: Induces vomiting.
column23: Plants For A Future can not take any responsibility for any adverse effects from the use of plants. Always seek advice from a professional before using a plant medicinally.Cathartic  EmeticThe fruit is cathartic and emetic[179].
column27: An easily grown plant, succeeding in any fertile soil, and preferring a good moist soil in a sunny position[11, 200]. There is at least one named variety, developed for its ornamental value. 'Guldperle' is from Denmark and has yellow berries[182].
column28: Seed - best sown as soon as it is ripe in a cold frame. Stored seed requires 2 months cold stratification[113] and should be sown as soon as possible in a cold frame. When they are large enough to handle, prick the seedlings out into individual pots and grow them on in the greenhouse for at least their first winter. Plant them out into their permanent positions in late spring or early summer, after the last expected frosts. Cuttings of half-ripe wood, 7 - 10cm with or without a heel, July/August in a frame. Good percentage[78]. Cuttings of mature wood of the current season's growth, 15 - 20cm with or without a heel, November in a cold frame. Good percentage[78]. Layering in autumn[200].
